questions.text: How quickly did the trouble breathing start?
When do you have trouble breathing?

options.label: With very little activity (like walking around the house)

questions.text: How bad is the trouble breathing right now?

options.label: A little short of breath, but I can talk in full sentences
I have to stop and catch my breath between sentences
I can barely get words out
I feel like I can't get enough air at all

questions.text: Is the breathing worse when you lie flat?

options.label: Yes, I have to sit up or prop myself up to breathe
No, it's the same in any position

questions.text: Do you also have chest pain?

options.label: Yes, sharp pain especially when I breathe in
Yes, coughing up clear or white mucus
Yes, coughing up yellow or green mucus
Yes, coughing up blood or pink frothy stuff

questions.text: Do you hear any wheezing or whistling sound when you breathe?
Are your legs or ankles swollen?
Do you have a fever or feel feverish?
Have you been on a long trip (car ride or flight), had surgery, or been stuck in bed recently?
Do you have asthma, COPD (lung disease), or any other breathing problem that's been diagnosed before?
Do you use an inhaler or breathing treatment? If so, has it helped?

options.label: Yes, but it didn't help this time

questions.text: Were you around anything you're allergic to, or did you eat something new before this started?
Is your face, lips, tongue, or throat swelling up?
Have you been waking up at night gasping for air?

red_flag_combinations.message: Severe trouble breathing needs immediate medical attention.
Sudden trouble breathing with sharp chest pain after being inactive could be a blood clot in the lung (pulmonary embolism). This is an emergency.
Sudden shortness of breath with swelling in one leg raises concern for a blood clot. This needs urgent evaluation.
Trouble breathing with chest pressure may be a heart problem. This needs immediate attention.
Trouble breathing when lying flat with swollen legs may be a sign of heart failure. This needs urgent care.
Coughing up blood or pink frothy mucus is a serious sign that needs immediate medical evaluation.
Swelling of the face, lips, tongue, or throat with trouble breathing could be a severe allergic reaction (anaphylaxis). This is a life-threatening emergency.
Trouble breathing that isn't getting better with your usual inhaler suggests a severe flare-up that needs emergency treatment.
Sudden trouble breathing at rest is a medical emergency.
Trouble breathing when lying flat, waking at night gasping, and swollen legs are signs of worsening heart failure. This needs emergency care.
